message_1: A factory has two production lines A and B. Line A produces 1000 units of a product in 8 hours while line B produces 800 units of the same product in 6 hours. If the factory operates for 9 hours a day, how many units of the product can the factory produce if it uses both production lines? (Assume that the production rate is constant)
message_2:
To find out how many units the factory can produce in 9 hours using both production lines, we first need to determine the production rate for each line.

Line A produces 1000 units in 8 hours, so its production rate is:
1000 units / 8 hours = 125 units/hour

Line B produces 800 units in 6 hours, so its production rate is:
800 units / 6 hours = 133.33 units/hour (rounded to two decimal places)

Now, we can calculate how many units each line will produce in 9 hours:

Line A: 125 units/hour * 9 hours = 1125 units
Line B: 133.33 units/hour * 9 hours = 1200 units (rounded to the nearest whole number)

So, if the factory uses both production lines for 9 hours, it can produce:
1125 units (Line A) + 1200 units (Line B) = 2325 units
